Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Temporal Variations in Pacific Ocean Dust Fluxes

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
This doctoral dissertation research project investigates the history of Asian dust deposition on islands in the Pacific and how variability in climate has impacted rates of dust deposition over the past 43,000 years. Asian dust from deserts contains iron and phosphorous, two nutrients that can greatly influence ecosystems in the North Pacific. Dust influxes have been influenced by differentials in three major processes, the amount of dust in the air, long-distance wind transport, and dust settling via rainfall to the ocean or soils. Despite these important connections, long-term records of temporal variations in Asian dust flux onto islands in the Pacific have not been reported. By analyzing proxy measures available in several cores extracted from peat bogs on Hawai'i, the doctoral student will generate an original long-term record of Asian dust flux on islands in the Pacific. This record will help better detect Asian dust flux-climate-ecosystem interactions, variations, and timescales beyond those available in modern observations. This new record will be made available through several broadly accessible databases which can be used by other investigators in ongoing efforts to model the role of dust in atmospheric processes. The research results will also be used to develop a science enrichment activity for minority and low-income high school students in Wisconsin.

The abundance of quartz in the soil of some Pacific islands such as Hawai'i demonstrates continuous addition of continental dust from East Asian deserts to the North Pacific. This project focuses on three research objectives: 1) reconstructing the history of quartz accumulation rates in Hawai'i; 2) distinguishing climate- from human-induced quartz flux in the paleodust records; and 3) comparing the quartz flux paleorecords with independent records of climate history to infer the influence of climate change on dust deposition in Hawai'i. Proxies include quartz accumulation rates for Asian dust flux, mean quartz grain size for the intensity of winds transporting Asian dust to Hawai'i, organic carbon accumulation, C/N ratio and Br content for Hawaiian paleohydrology, and mean grain size distribution for human-induced local dust emission intensity. By reconstructing and correlating these proxies, the doctoral student will demonstrate how climatologic variation has influenced Asian dust flux in Hawai'i over the last 43,000 years. The results will contribute to ongoing efforts to model the linkages among climate, atmospheric dust, and connections among remote ecosystems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project presents the first Hawaiian dust accumulation records from peat sediments that cover the last 45,000 years. The Hawaiian records show temporal variability in three different dust-related variables, the depositional composition of Hawaiian local dust relative to continental dust from East Asia, grain size distribution, and deposition rates of Asian dust arriving in Hawaii. These geological data provide scientific evidence that Hawaiian local dust and Asian dust both accumulated in Hawaii, with greater accumulation rates during the last glacial period than the present. The project investigated whether the higher deposition of Hawaiian local dust during the last glacial period was related to decreased precipitation in Hawaii. High rates of Asian dust flux were associated with increased aridity in East Asian continental deserts and intensification of the jet stream, which transports dust from Asia to Hawaii.

The project provides new long-term data on Asian dust flux to the low-latitude Pacific. The Pacific region has few dust monitoring stations or paleodust records, posing great challenges to our understanding of dust transport processes. The Hawaiian dust accumulation data allow investigation of how the quantity of Asian dust deposition responded to changes in prominent climatic drivers over time. In addition, this project contributes to understanding of biogeochemical impacts of Hawaiian local dust in Hawaiian rainforest ecosystems. The project found that more Hawaiian local dust from non-alkalic basalt was produced during the last glacial period than in the present time. Previous research on Hawaiian ecosystems and soil development focused on the biogeochemical role of Asian dust in Hawaii. The new finding suggests a hypothesis that locally derived dust-borne nutrients are significant nutrient sources in Hawaiian wet forest ecosystems. 

The project offered research tranining for a female graduate student at the University of Wisconsin-Madison. By completing data generation and analysis for her dissertation research, she improved her geochemical and statistical analyticial skills. Her samples and data also made significant contributions to other graduate students' thesis projects. In addition, the data spurred educational activities for undergraduate research, tranining and teaching, developing the graduate student's mentoring skills.
